2Design and Technology of Recommender Sy.context1: Is it possible to imitate human judgment using a computerized informationretrieval system? Users expect search engines todeliver answers to their queries, no matter how idiosyncraticor imprecise the formulation of their search." Recommender systems support usersby identifying interestingproductsandservices insituations where the number and complexity of offers outstrips the users capability to survey them and reach a decision 2].
2Design and Technology of Recommender Sy.context2: There exist six important software processes which attempt to weave human judgment into a computational process, with as littleexplicit humaneffort as possible.Theyareas fol lows:

2.1 Cluster Analysis.context1: Clusteranalysis is a mathematical process which identifies groups of objects which have similar attributes when the attributes are otherwise unknown.For the purposes of marketing,the theory behind the usefulness of cluster analysis is that consumers who have similar demographics and/or lifestyles will have simi lar purchasing habits and preferences.The weakness of cluster analysis is that it tends to result in a construct of very few groups and as a result does not have high accuracy and then usefulness for one-toonemarketing[3] .

2.2Collaborative Filtering.context1: Col laborative Filtering is the most successful e-commerce technology for recommender systems. Collaborative filtering attempts to resolve the problem of substituting human judgment with computer technology by identifying customers with simi lar purchasing choices to the target customer.The system then makes recommendations to the target customer based on the purchases made by other consumers who have purchased the same items that the target customer has purchased in the past.A familiar example of acol laborative filtering system is the system popularizedby Amazon. com[4].

2.3CRM.context1: Customer Relationship Management(CRM) is a strategy to collect, store and analyze data from existing customers in order to analyze customer behavior and plan targeted marketing strategies. The focus is on existing customers and on using customer data for targeting. Quatsel3] notes that using CRM for one-to-one marketing is not simple or efficient because with CRM, the" human judgment issue is resolved bya human operator, typicallyan IT professional or specialist at the task, who passes judgment on which group of customers might be the most likely targets for each promotional offer.'Therefore, the process is not solely driven by computer technologies,but requireshuman intervention,andasignificant investment of time and human resources.

2.4Statistical Inference.context1: Statistical Inference is a recommender system based on consumer behavior in physical stores and takes into consideration the differences between e-commerce and brick andmortar stores.In this system,“ a model of each customer is based upon the statistics of previous purchases and the probability of a future purchase is inferred from the model."lThemajordifference in the design concept is that the Statistical Inference system is designedaround consumableitems whichare repeatedlypurchased (toothpaste,toilet paper, bananas, etc.) as opposed to the type of items one would typically purchase from a vendor such as Amazon.com, which are likely to be aonetime purchaseof aparticularbookor CD, for example.Therefore, the Statistical Inference system focuses on the repeated purchases of aparticular consumer,as opposed to thesimi larities in purchases among different consumers.The system is clearly more useful for physical storesthan fortypical onlinetransactions.

2.5Social Data Mining.context1: Social Data Miningdescribes mined preferences from the World Wide Web analyzing social online activity such as Usenet messages, usage logs and hyperlinks.Information is extracted and used to designand transmit information, which isusually transmitted viaa broadcast to a group as opposed to direct targeting toan individual consumer. With this process, the intended audience will receive the recommender broadcast whether or not he is expecting or intentionallyseeking recommendations[5].

2.6Social Networking.context1: Social networking acts as informal recommender systems amongst users who" tag'their favorite websites. Users can search the site by keyword and see lists of different websites that have been" tagged 'by their peers.Instead of having bookmarks on your personal computer they can be kept at the site where you and others can access them.Aperson only needs access to the net to find their favorite websites and learn about others that are popular as well.

2.7Cross System Personalization.context1: Cross System Personalization isa relatively recent development in the field of recommender systems and personalization, which allows the user limited control over information built up and mustalso be repeated for everywebsite in some fashion.The initial thought was to create a user passport that could be carried and presented from one system to the next, but that would require systems having some sort of global ly accepted semantics.A later idea involved the use of machine learning techniques which would eliminate the need for globally accepted semantics.The key idea is that one can try to learn dependencies between profiles maintained within one system and profiles maintained within a second system based on data provided by users who use both systems and who are willing to share their profiles across systems which we assume is in the interestof theuser[6].

2.8 Recommender Support System.context1: Recommender Support System does not automate the process of making a recommendation,but rather provides tools to permit individuals to share recommendations with others.This type of system is also used by Amazon.com where users are invited to createannotated listsof recommendations usinga feature referred to as‘ Listmania.5]
2.8 Recommender Support System.context2: All of these technological systems are designed with the goal of replacing normal human social interaction with effective computer intervention in order to create and communicate meaningful recommendations toa target audience.

5Conclusion.context2: Implementations of recommender systems indigital libraries relies heavily on the collaboration of professionals in various disciplines, including information, libraryandcomputerscience,to ensure the greatest benefit for individuals while at the same time allowing them to manage the increasing amounts of data on the net without sacrificing their privacy.The public has become accustomed to the service and usefulness of recommender systems in ecommerce and in Internet searching and will likely appreciate and benefit from an application of this technology to library services.
